page.title: 01THE BACK-BONE OF LLYN
page.content: This bit of land in the heart of Llyn has not changed much for centuries. The land rises from Gors Geirch (70' A.S.L) to 700' on Barn Saethon and Carneddol, falls to 200' along the deep V-shaped Nanhoron Valley then rises to 900' and 1,200' on Carn Bach and Carn Fadryn. The land below these scree-covered hills is divided with stone walls into minute fields, whereas the rest of the area consist of bigger fields, rough grazing enclosures, bracken covered slopes and some trees. A few narrow roads run through. Of tje 50 or so families, about 1/3 earn their living entirely on the land while some are smallholders with another occupation, beef and sheep farming is most common. Though summer visitors are a common source of income, it has escaped the brunt of the tourist industry which is
